instruction:
A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.

Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful
output:
Here is a job description based on the provided information:

**Job Title:** Software Engineer

**Company:** [Company name]

**Job Summary:**

We are seeking a talented and motivated Software Engineer to join our dynamic team. As a Software Engineer at [Company name], you will have the opportunity to work on complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark. If you have a passion for coding, collaboration, and problem-solving, we encourage you to apply for this exciting role.

**Responsibilities:**

* Collaborate with fellow software engineers to design, develop, test, and debug complex software applications
* Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers to ensure high-quality code
* Write comprehensive unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest
* Work closely with business stakeholders to understand their requirements and build features that meet their needs
* Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark
* Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects to ensure timely resolution

**Requirements:**

* Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or a related field
* Experience with a modern software programming language, such as Python
* Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
* Strong written and verbal communication skills
* Ability to work in a highly-collaborative environment
* Eagerness to learn and grow with the company
* Experience with SQL queries and data analysis applications is an asset
* Familiarity with visualization tools such as Tableau or PowerBI is a plus

**What We Offer:**

* Competitive salary and benefits package
* Opportunity to work on complex and challenging projects
* Collaborative and dynamic work environment
* Professional growth and development opportunities
* Flexible working hours and remote work options

**Why Join Us:**

At [Company name], we prioritize innovation, collaboration, and customer satisfaction. We believe in empowering our employees to take ownership of their work and providing them with the resources they need to succeed. If you share our values and are passionate about software engineering, we encourage you to apply for this exciting opportunity.

instruction:

output:

[Company Logo]
[Your Company Name]
[Date]

[Candidate Name]
[Address]

Dear [Candidate Name],

I wanted to personally reach out to you regarding the status of your application for [Position] at [Company Name]. We appreciate the time and effort you took to interview with us and share your qualifications with our team.

After careful consideration, I regret to inform you that we will not be moving forward with your candidacy at this time. While your skills and experience are impressive, we have decided to offer the position to another candidate whose qualifications and fit are particularly well-suited to the role.

Please know that this decision was not made lightly, and we were impressed by your performance during the interview process. We recognize that this news may be disappointing, and I want to assure you that it is in no way a reflection on your abilities or potential as a candidate.

We appreciate your interest in joining our team and wish you the best of luck in your job search. If you have any questions or would like feedback on your application, please do not hesitate to reach out.

Thank you again for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

[Your Title]

**Section 1: Introduction**

* Briefly explain the stress of last-minute gift giving

instruction:
Write a section for a blog post and try to cover all of the provided information about this section in your text.

Blog Topic: 7 Fall Fashion Trends Worth Taking on Your Trip
Section Title: Trusty Jeans
Main point of the section: jeans can be worn all year and look good with everything .
output:
**Trusty Jeans: A Fall Fashion Staple That Never Goes Out of Style**

One of the most versatile and essential pieces in any wardrobe, jeans are a fashion staple that can be worn all year round, regardless of the season. And as the leaves start to change and fall fashion begins to take center stage, you might be surprised at just how stylish and relevant a good pair of jeans can be. From casual days out to dressy nights on the town, jeans are a trusty companion that can be paired with just about anything in your closet.

Whether you opt for a classic straight-leg cut, a trendy high-waisted style, or a more distressed, ripped look, jeans have the power to elevate even the most basic of outfits. And with the fall season's focus on cozying up in layers, jeans can be easily paired with boots, cardigans, and even a statement jacket or coat to create a look that's both stylish and practical.

What's more, jeans are incredibly easy to care for, making them a great choice for travelers who want to pack light and minimize laundry worries on the go. And as the weather cools down, you can enjoy the added comfort and warmth that a pair of jeans provides. Whether you're exploring the great outdoors, strolling through the city, or simply lounging around the hotel room, trusty jeans are sure to be a reliable and stylish choice for your fall fashion needs.

instruction:
Using the provided topic as a starting point, brainstorm ideas for videos that can be made about it on YouTube.

In spite of the fact that procrastination feels bad to you, why do you do it?
output:
What a relatable topic! Here are some video ideas that can help tackle this issue on YouTube:

**Explainer Videos**

1. "Why We Procrastinate: The Science Behind Delaying Tasks" - a 3-minute animated video explaining the psychology and neuroscience behind procrastination.
2. "The 5 Most Common Reasons We Procrastinate (And How to Overcome Them)" - a straightforward, informative video exploring the root causes of procrastination.

**Personal Stories and Reflections**

1. "My Personal Struggle with Procrastination: How I Overcame It" - a vlog-style video where the creator shares their own experiences with procrastination and how they overcame it.
2. "Interview with a Procrastinator: Uncovering the Hidden Fears and Excuses" - a conversational video where the creator interviews someone who struggles with procrastination, exploring their thoughts, feelings, and motivations.

**Productivity and Time Management Tips**

1. "10 Simple Productivity Hacks to Help You Stay Focused and Avoid Procrastination" - a practical video sharing actionable tips and strategies to boost productivity.
2. "Time Management for Procrastinators: A Step-by-Step Guide to Getting Started" - a video breaking down a systematic approach to managing time effectively.

**Psychological and Emotional Insights**

1. "The Emotional Reasons We Procrastinate: Understanding the Subconscious Fears and Anxieties" - a thought-provoking video examining the emotional underpinnings of procrastination.
2. "Overcoming Procrastination Anxiety: Strategies for Building Confidence and Self-Esteem" - a video offering advice on how to confront and overcome anxiety related to procrastination.

**Humorous and Light-Hearted Approaches**

1. "Procrastination Showdown: A Funny Take on the Struggle" - a humorous video poking fun at the self-defeating behaviors associated with procrastination.
2. "The Best (Worst?) Excuses for Procrastination: A Lighthearted Look at the Most Creative Reasons for Putting Things Off" - a comedic video showcasing the absurdities of procrastination.

**Inspirational and Motivational Content**

1. "From Procrastination to Productivity: Real-Life Success Stories to Inspire You" - a motivational video featuring examples of people who've overcome procrastination and achieved success.
2. "The Power of Accountability: How to Create a Procrastination-Free Environment" - a video exploring the benefits of accountability and offering tips on how to create a supportive system to stay focused.

These video ideas should provide a solid starting point for creating engaging and informative content about procrastination and how to overcome it.

instruction:
Find the answer that best describes the underlined SAT word. Select the correct option and explain the meaning of the underlined word.

Despite the _cacophony, the student tried to study. 
A. Loud sounds
B. Difficult subject
C. Late hour
D. Low lighting
output:
The correct answer is A. Loud sounds.

The underlined word "cacophony" refers to a harsh, discordant sound, often a mixture of loud or unpleasant noises. In this sentence, the student is trying to study despite the unpleasant and distracting sounds around them, which create a cacophony.

Cacophony is often used to describe a situation where multiple sounds are clashing or competing with each other, creating a jarring or unpleasant atmosphere. For example, a city street with construction, sirens, and loud music might be described as a cacophony.

instruction:
Find synonyms for the given word. You need to write down how the provided synonyms differ from the original word in terms of meaning, usage, etc.

adversity
output:
Here are some synonyms for the word "adversity" along with their differences from the original word:

1. **Trouble**: Trouble is a more general term that can refer to any kind of difficult situation or problem, whereas adversity is often used to describe a difficult or challenging situation that is caused by external factors, such as fate, circumstance, or bad luck.

Usage: "I've been having trouble sleeping" vs. "I've been facing adversity in my personal life".

2. **Hardship**: Hardship is a synonym for adversity that emphasizes the difficulty or severity of the situation. While adversity can refer to any kind of challenging situation, hardship implies a more intense or prolonged struggle.

Usage: "The family faced hardship during the economic downturn" vs. "The athlete faced adversity when he was injured mid-game".

3. **Calamity**: Calamity is a more extreme synonym for adversity, implying a sudden, severe, and often disastrous event. While adversity can refer to a prolonged or gradual difficulty, calamity is typically used to describe a short-term, intense crisis.

Usage: "The natural disaster was a calamity for the small town" vs. "The team faced adversity during the playoffs".

4. **Obstacle**: An obstacle is a more concrete and specific synonym for adversity, implying a particular challenge or hindrance that must be overcome. While adversity is a more general term that can refer to any kind of difficult situation, an obstacle is a more tangible and immediate challenge.

Usage: "The athlete faced an obstacle in the form of an injured teammate" vs. "The entrepreneur faced adversity when the market changed overnight".

5. **Struggle**: Struggle is a more intense and personal synonym for adversity, implying a prolonged and emotionally draining effort to overcome a challenge. While adversity is a more general term that can refer to any kind of difficult situation, struggle emphasizes the personal and emotional aspects of the experience.

Usage: "The artist struggled to find inspiration for her next project" vs. "The community struggled with poverty and unemployment".

These synonyms offer different connotations, nuances, and implications for the original word "adversity".

instruction:
Discuss the origins and history of the word that has been given to you.

oblique
output:
The word "oblique" has a rich history dating back to ancient times. The word comes from the Latin "obliquus," which means "slanting" or "diagonal." This Latin word is derived from the prefix "ob-" (meaning "against" or "contrary to") and the verb "liquus" (meaning "to lean" or "to slope").

The first recorded use of the word "oblique" in English dates back to the 14th century, during the Middle English period. During this time, the word was used to describe something that was not straight or upright, but rather slanted or diagonal. For example, a sentence from Chaucer's Canterbury Tales reads: "The sunne was high in oblique ascendant."

Over time, the meaning of the word "oblique" expanded to include other connotations. In the 16th century, the word began to be used to describe language that was indirect or ambiguous, rather than direct and straightforward. This sense of the word is still found in modern English, where "oblique" is often used to describe speech or writing that is evasive or unclear.

In addition to its literary and linguistic connotations, the word "oblique" has also been used in various scientific and technical contexts. In geometry, an oblique angle is one that is not a right angle (90 degrees) or a straight angle (180 degrees). In astronomy, an oblique orbit is one that is not a perfect circle, but rather an ellipse.

Throughout history, the word "oblique" has been influenced by various languages and cultures. For example, the Latin "obliquus" has parallels in other Indo-European languages, such as Greek "oblikos" and Old Church Slavonic "oblukh." The word has also been used in various idiomatic expressions and phrases, such as "to speak obliquely" or "to take an oblique approach," which reflect its evolving connotations and uses.

In conclusion, the word "oblique" has a long and complex history that reflects its multifaceted meanings and uses. From its origins in ancient Latin to its modern connotations in literature and science, the word has undergone significant changes and adaptations, yet remains a rich and evocative term in the English language.

Dear [Recipient's Name],

instruction: You need to write an email to negotiate your salary.
output:
Here's an example email you could use as a template:

Subject: Request for Salary Negotiation

Dear [Hiring Manager's Name],

I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to express my gratitude for the offer extended to me for the [Position] role at [Company Name]. I am excited about the opportunity to join your team and contribute to the company's success.

After careful consideration, I wanted to discuss the salary for the position. Based on my research, I believe my skills and experience align with the market average for this role. I would like to request a salary of [Specific Number or Range] per year. This figure is based on my research of industry standards and salaries for similar positions in the area.

I want to emphasize that I am very interested in the opportunity to join your team and am excited about the prospect of working with [Company Name]. However, I also need to consider my own financial situation and ensure that the salary is commensurate with my skills and experience.

I would appreciate it if we could discuss this request further and explore the possibility of revising the salary to meet my expectations. I am confident that we can work together to find a mutually beneficial solution.

If we are unable to come to an agreement on a salary, I would still like to express my interest in the position and discuss other benefits or perks that could make the opportunity more competitive.

Please let me know if we can schedule a call to discuss this further. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Best regards,

[Your Name]

Some tips to keep in mind when negotiating your salary:

* Do your research: Know the market average salary for your role and industry to make an informed request.
* Be confident but respectful: Be assertive and clear about your request, but also be open to negotiation and willing to compromise.
* Focus on your value: Instead of just asking for a certain amount, explain why you believe your skills and experience warrant that salary.
* Be prepared to negotiate: The employer may not agree to your initial request, so be prepared to make a counteroffer or compromise.
* Don't be afraid to walk away: If you don't feel that the salary is fair, it may be better to explore other opportunities rather than accepting a salary that doesn't meet your needs.

Remember that salary negotiation is a normal part of the hiring process, and it's okay to ask for what you're worth. Good luck!

instruction: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.
output:
Here is a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts:

**Step 1: Identify the Merge Conflict**

* Open the pull request that is causing the conflict in your GitHub repository.
* Click on the "Files changed" tab, which will show you the files that are affected by the merge conflict.
* Look for files with a warning icon () next to them. These files have conflicts that need to be resolved.

**Step 2: Open the Conflict File**

* Click on the file with a warning icon to open it in a new tab or window.
* You will see the file with both versions of the code present, separated by a conflict marker (e.g. `<<<<<<<` `=======` `>>>>>>>`).

**Step 3: Review the Conflict**

* Read through the file to understand the changes that were made in both branches.
* Determine which changes you want to keep and which changes you want to discard.

**Step 4: Resolve the Conflict**

* Make the necessary changes to the file to resolve the conflict.
* You can delete or modify sections of the file as needed.
* If you're using a code editor, you may want to use features like "diff" or "merge" tools to help you resolve the conflict.

**Step 5: Mark the Conflict as Resolved**

* Once you've resolved the conflict, highlight the entire conflict marker (e.g. `<<<<<<<` `=======` `>>>>>>>`) and delete it.
* Save the file with the latest version of the code.

**Step 6: Stage the Resolved File**

* Go to the terminal or command line and navigate to the root of your repository.
* Use the `git add <file_name>` command to stage the resolved file. For example: `git add conflicted_file.txt`.

**Step 7: Commit the Changes**

* Use the `git commit -m "Resolved merge conflict"` command to commit the changes.
* Make sure to include a meaningful commit message that describes the changes you made to resolve the conflict.

**Step 8: Push the Changes**

* Use the `git push` command to push the changes to your remote repository.

**Step 9: Push the Changes to GitHub**

* Go back to your GitHub repository and refresh the pull request page.
* You should see that the conflict has been resolved and the pull request can now be merged.

**Tips and Tricks**

* Always resolve conflicts in a local branch, not directly in the upstream branch.
* Use `git status` and `git log` commands to track your changes and resolve conflicts.
* If you're having trouble resolving a conflict, try using a merge tool or seeking help from a colleague or mentor.
* Don't forget to test your code after resolving a conflict to ensure that it works as expected.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve GitHub merge conflicts efficiently and effectively.

instruction:
One or more jobs can be run automatically by a workflow. The workflows are defined in the repository as YAML files and will run if an event occurs in the repository, as well as manually, or on a certain schedule.
Bring an example of a workflow that demonstrate the CI/CD features of GitHub Actions.
output:
Here's an example of a GitHub Actions workflow that demonstrates CI/CD features:

**Workflow Name:** Build, Test, and Deploy to Production

**Purpose:** This workflow automates the build, test, and deployment of a Node.js application to production when code changes are pushed to the `main` branch.

**workflow.yml:**
```yaml
name: Build, Test, and Deploy to Production

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  build-and-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: npm install

      - name: Build and test
        run: npm run build && npm run test

      - name: Deploy to production
        uses: actions/deploy@v1
        with:
          business-username: ${{ secrets.BUSINESS_USERNAME }}
          access-token: ${{ secrets.ACCESS_TOKEN }}
          provider: github
          repository: my-repo
          ref: main
          token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
```
**Breakdown:**

1. The workflow is triggered on push events to the `main` branch.
2. The workflow consists of a single job, `build-and-deploy`, which runs on an `ubuntu-latest` environment.
3. The job has four steps:
	* `Checkout code`: Fetches the latest code from the repository using the `actions/checkout` action.
	* `Install dependencies`: Runs `npm install` to install dependencies required by the application.
	* `Build and test`: Runs `npm run build` to build the application and `npm run test` to run tests.
	* `Deploy to production`: Uses the `actions/deploy` action to deploy the application to production. This step requires secrets for business-username, access-token, and GITHUB_TOKEN.

**Secrets:**

* `BUSINESS_USERNAME`: stored as a secret in the GitHub repository settings
* `ACCESS_TOKEN`: stored as a secret in the GitHub repository settings
* `GITHUB_TOKEN`: generated by GitHub Actions automatically

**CI/CD Features:**

1. **Continuous Integration (CI)**: The workflow automatically builds and tests the application when code changes are pushed to the `main` branch.
2. **Continuous Deployment (CD)**: The workflow automatically deploys the application to production when the build and test steps pass.
3. **Environment Variables**: The workflow uses environment variables (secrets) to store sensitive information, such as API tokens and business usernames.
4. **GitHub Actions**: The workflow uses GitHub Actions to automate the build, test, and deployment process.

This example demonstrates a simple CI/CD pipeline that automates the build, test, and deployment of a Node.js application to production. You can customize and extend this workflow to fit your specific needs.

instruction:
You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.

Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.
output:
After reading the reviews, I extracted the following points:

Positive points:

* Innovative story
* Strong script
* Engaging characters
* Intense cinematography
* Great acting
* Important messages
* Unorthodox way of conveying messages
* Fascinating visual effects
* Compelling story (up to the second half)

Negative points:

* Ed Norton's performance grates on some people
* The movie starts to fall apart halfway through
* Becomes tedious towards the end
* Lacks connection to the audience
* Leaves viewers in confusion
* Considered overrated by some
* Does not end well

Here is a summary of the positive and negative points mentioned in the reviews:

**Positive Points:**

The movie has several positive aspects, including its innovative story, strong script, engaging characters, and intense cinematography. The acting is also praised, and the movie conveys important messages in an unorthodox way. Additionally, the visual effects are fascinating, and the story is compelling until the second half.

**Negative Points:**

Some people find Ed Norton's performance annoying, and the movie starts to lose its direction halfway through. The pacing becomes slow and tedious towards the end, and some viewers are left confused. The movie is also considered overrated by some, and the ending is disappointing.

instruction:
Give a brief summary of the movie or series' plot.

Breaking Bad (TV Series 2008–2013)
output:
Here's a brief summary of the plot of Breaking Bad:

Walter White (played by Bryan Cranston), a high school chemistry teacher, is diagnosed with terminal lung cancer. Feeling desperate and wanting to secure his family's financial future after his death, Walter partners with Jesse Pinkman (played by Aaron Paul), a former student and small-time methamphetamine manufacturer, to cook and sell methamphetamine.

As the series progresses, Walter's transformation from a mundane high school teacher to a notorious meth kingpin, known by his alias "Heisenberg," becomes more intense. His family, including his wife Skyler (Anna Gunn) and teenage son Walter Jr. (RJ Mitte), becomes increasingly entangled in his illegal activities.

Throughout the series, Walter's ego and sense of self-importance grow, leading him to make poor decisions that put himself and those around him in harm's way. Meanwhile, the authorities, led by Hank Schrader (Dean Norris), Walter's DEA brother-in-law, are hot on the trail of the mysterious "Heisenberg" and his accomplices.

The show explores themes of morality, family, power, and the consequences of one's actions, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats with its intense plot twists and character developments.

instruction:
Decide whether children can watch the given movie. Mention what makes it inappropriate if you think they can't.

The Dark Knight (2008)
output:
I would not recommend The Dark Knight (2008) for young children. Here's why:

* Violent content: The movie features intense and graphic violence, including explosions, gunfights, and brutal fight scenes between superheroes and villains. This may be disturbing for younger children.
* Mature themes: The film explores complex and mature themes, such as the nature of evil, chaos, and the consequences of vigilantism. These themes may be difficult for children to understand or process.
* Scary elements: The Joker, played by Heath Ledger, is a terrifying villain who is responsible for many of the violent and disturbing scenes in the movie. His unpredictable behavior and unsettling appearance may be too intense for younger children.
* Complex plot: The movie has a complex and layered plot, which may be difficult for younger children to follow.

I would recommend The Dark Knight for children aged 13 and above, depending on their individual maturity level and sensitivity to violence and scary themes. However, it's essential for parents or guardians to use their discretion and consider the child's age, sensitivity, and emotional well-being before allowing them to watch the movie.

instruction:
Write a short analysis of the cinematography in the movie.

Dead Poets Society
output:
The cinematography in the 1989 film "Dead Poets Society" is noteworthy for its use of vibrant colors, natural lighting, and sweeping camera movements that capture the beauty and drama of the story. Here are some key elements that contribute to the film's visually stunning aesthetic:

1. Color Palette: The film's color palette is characterized by a mix of earthy tones, such as greens, browns, and blues, which reflect the idyllic setting of the elite prep school in New England. The colors are rich and muted, which adds to the film's sense of nostalgia and tradition.
2. Lighting: The cinematography makes effective use of natural light, often capturing the warmth and softness of sunlight filtering through leaves or dancing across the characters' faces. This creates a sense of authenticity and humanity, particularly in scenes where the characters are interacting with nature.
3. Camera Movement: The camera work is often fluid and dynamic, using sweeping movements to capture the characters' movements and capturing the sense of freedom and rebellion that defines the story. For example, during the iconic "Carpe Diem" poetry reading, the camera moves through the room, following the characters as they recite their poems with passion and emotion.
4. Compositional Framing: The cinematography often employs clever compositional framing, using the environment to reflect the characters' emotions and relationships. For example, during a confrontation between Charlie Dalton (Robbie Coltrane) and Mr. Keating (Robin Williams), the camera frames them in a tight, claustrophobic space, emphasizing the tension and conflict between them.
5. Use of Landscape: The film makes effective use of the school's surroundings, often incorporating the natural beauty of the New England landscape into the storytelling. For example, the character of Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard) is shown exploring the woods, symbolizing his desire for artistic expression and rebellion against the conformity of his prep school environment.

Overall, the cinematography in "Dead Poets Society" is a key element in creating the film's sense of atmosphere and tone. The use of vibrant colors, natural lighting, and dynamic camera movements helps to convey the film's themes of rebellion, self-discovery, and the power of art to transform lives.

instruction:
Please let me know your thoughts on the given place and why you think it deserves to be visited.

Barcelona, Spain
output:
Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, Spain! What a vibrant and captivating city! Barcelona is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in art, architecture, culture, food, and relaxation. Here's why:

**Architecture and Landmarks**: Barcelona is home to some of the most iconic and awe-inspiring architecture in the world. The works of Antoni Gaudí, a renowned Catalan architect, are a highlight of the city. Visit the Sagrada Família, Park Güell, Casa Batlló, and La Pedrera, all of which showcase Gaudí's unique and imaginative style. The city's Gothic Quarter, with its narrow streets and medieval buildings, is also a treasure trove of architectural history.

**Beaches and Parks**: Barcelona has some of the most beautiful and bustling beaches in Europe, such as Barceloneta and Nova Icària. The city also boasts numerous parks and gardens, like the famous Parc de la Ciutadella, which offers a peaceful escape from the urban bustle. The Montjuïc Hill, with its stunning views of the city and the sea, is another must-visit spot.

**Cuisine**: Catalan cuisine is a fusion of Mediterranean flavors, with influences from the sea, mountains, and countryside. Try traditional dishes like pa amb tomàquet (bread with tomato), tapas, seafood, and patatas bravas. Don't forget to indulge in some delicious Spanish wine and cava!

**Culture and Festivals**: Barcelona is a city that loves to celebrate, with numerous festivals throughout the year. The La Mercè festival, held in September, is a highlight, featuring music, dance, and street performances. The city is also home to the famous Palau de la Música Catalana concert hall, which hosts a wide range of musical performances.

**Museums and Art**: Barcelona has a thriving cultural scene, with numerous museums and galleries showcasing the works of local and international artists. The Picasso Museum, the Joan Miró Museum, and the Museum of Contemporary Art (MACBA) are just a few examples.

**Nightlife**: Barcelona has a lively nightlife scene, with bars, clubs, and live music venues to suit all tastes. The famous La Rambla street is a great place to start your night out, with its street performers, restaurants, and bars.

**Accessibility**: Barcelona is well-connected to the rest of Europe and the world, with El Prat Airport (BCN) serving as a hub for flights. The city's public transportation system is also efficient and easy to navigate, making it easy to get around without a car.

Overall, Barcelona is a city that will captivate your senses, inspire your imagination, and leave you with lifelong memories. Whether you're interested in art, architecture, food, culture, or simply relaxation, Barcelona has something for everyone.

instruction:
Consider the best time of year to visit the given city, and provide your reasons for choosing that time.

Sydney, Australia
output:
The best time to visit Sydney, Australia is during the spring season (September to November) and the autumn season (March to May). Here's why:

**Spring:**

1. Mild weather: The temperature is pleasant, ranging from 12°C to 22°C (54°F to 72°F), making it ideal for outdoor activities like visiting beaches, parks, and taking harbor cruises.
2. Beautiful blooming flowers: Spring is the perfect time to see Sydney's famous gardens and parks in full bloom, including the Royal Botanic Garden and the Sydney Opera House's gardens.
3. Fewer crowds: Compared to the peak summer months, spring has fewer tourists, making it easier to explore popular attractions like the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House without the crowds.
4. festivals and events: Spring is a great time to experience Sydney's cultural events, such as the Sydney Spring Festival, Vivid Sydney (light festival), and the Sydney Film Festival.

**Autumn:**

1. Comfortable weather: Autumn brings mild temperatures, ranging from 10°C to 20°C (50°F to 68°F), perfect for exploring the city's outdoor attractions.
2. Whale watching: Autumn is the best time to spot humpback whales migrating along the coast, offering a unique and unforgettable experience.
3. Harvest season: Autumn is the harvest season in Australia, and Sydney's farmers' markets are filled with fresh produce, cheeses, and other local goodies.
4. Fewer crowds: Like spring, autumn has fewer tourists than summer, making it an excellent time to visit popular attractions without the crowds.

Overall, the spring and autumn seasons offer the perfect balance of comfortable weather, fewer crowds, and exciting events and experiences, making them the best times to visit Sydney.

instruction: Make a questionnaire to help hotel guests write hotel reviews.
output:
Here's a sample questionnaire to help hotel guests write hotel reviews:

**Hotel Review Questionnaire**

**Overall Stay**

1. How would you rate your overall stay at this hotel? (Scale: 1-5, where 1 is "Poor" and 5 is "Excellent")
2. Would you stay at this hotel again? (Yes/No)

**Room**

1. How would you rate the cleanliness and upkeep of your room? (Scale: 1-5)
2. Was your room comfortable and well-appointed? (Scale: 1-5)
3. Were there any issues with noise or disturbance during your stay? (Yes/No)

**Amenities**

1. How did you find the hotel's amenities, such as the fitness center, pool, etc.? (Scale: 1-5)
2. Were there any amenities that you felt were missing or could be improved? (Check all that apply)

* Fitness center
* Pool
* Restaurant
* Bar
* Room service
* Laundry facilities
* Other (please specify)

**Service**

1. How would you rate the helpfulness and courtesy of the hotel staff? (Scale: 1-5)
2. Were there any issues with service, such as long wait times or unresponsive staff? (Yes/No)

**Food and Beverage**

1. If you used the hotel's restaurant or room service, how would you rate the quality and variety of food options? (Scale: 1-5)
2. Were the prices of food and beverages reasonable? (Yes/No)

**Location**

1. How would you rate the hotel's location and proximity to local attractions and transportation? (Scale: 1-5)
2. Were there any issues with noise or disturbance from the surrounding area? (Yes/No)

**Additional Comments**

1. What were some highlights of your stay at this hotel?
2. Are there any areas where the hotel could improve?
3. Do you have any suggestions for future guests?

**Demographic Information (optional)**

1. Are you a business traveler or leisure traveler? (Business/Leisure)
2. How did you find this hotel (e.g. online search, recommendation, etc.)?

This questionnaire should give hotel guests a helpful framework for writing a comprehensive and balanced review.

instruction:
Make a list of the top places in the U.S. to visit at the given time.

November
output:
November! A great time to visit the U.S. as the weather is mild, and the summer crowds have dissipated. Here are some top places to visit in the U.S. during November:

1. **New York City, New York**: Experience the magical atmosphere of the Big Apple during the holiday season. Visit the iconic Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, ice skate at Bryant Park, or catch a performance of the Radio City Christmas Spectacular.
2. **San Francisco, California**: Enjoy the Golden Gate City's festive atmosphere, including the annual Christmas lights ceremony in Union Square. Take a stroll across the Golden Gate Bridge, visit Alcatraz Island, or explore the vibrant neighborhoods of Haight-Ashbury and the Mission District.
3. **Nashville, Tennessee**: Country music fans, rejoice! Visit Music City in November to enjoy the CMA Awards, country music festivals, and live performances at the Bluebird Cafe. Don't miss the famous Broadway Honky Tonk Highway.
4. **Asheville, North Carolina**: This charming mountain town is a haven for outdoor enthusiasts. Take a hike in the Blue Ridge Mountains, explore the River Arts District, or visit the Biltmore Estate, which is especially beautiful during the fall season.
5. **New Orleans, Louisiana**: Get ready for a festive and spooky atmosphere in the Big Easy. Visit the French Quarter, take a haunted history tour, or enjoy the Voodoo Fest music festival.
6. **Denver, Colorado**: With the Rockies as a backdrop, Denver is a great place to visit in November. Enjoy the Denver Broncos football season, visit the Colorado State Capitol, or take a stroll through the vibrant LoDo neighborhood.
7. **Seattle, Washington**: Experience the Pacific Northwest's fall foliage in Seattle, which is surrounded by mountains and water. Visit the iconic space needle, Pike Place Market, or take a ferry ride to Bainbridge Island.
8. **Austin, Texas**: This lively city is perfect for outdoor enthusiasts. Take a dip in Barton Springs Pool, hike at McKinney Falls State Park, or enjoy the vibrant food truck scene on South Congress Avenue.
9. **Portland, Oregon**: Known for its quirky vibe, Portland is a great place to visit in November. Explore the Japanese Garden, visit the renowned Powell's City of Books, or take a walk through Forest Park.
10. **Chicago, Illinois**: The Windy City is a must-visit in November, with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's holiday concerts, the Christkindlmarket food fest, and the iconic Willis Tower (formerly Sears Tower) offering breathtaking city views.

These are just a few of the many amazing places to visit in the U.S. during November. Each location offers a unique blend of fall festivities, outdoor activities, and cultural attractions that are sure to make your trip unforgettable!

instruction: Name the top cities in France that should not be missed. Include the best aspects of each place as well.
output:
France, the land of love, art, fashion, and cuisine! There are countless charming cities to explore in this beautiful country, but here are the top cities in France that should not be missed, along with their best aspects:

1. **Paris** (Île-de-France)
	* The City of Light is famous for: The Eiffel Tower, Notre-Dame Cathedral, Louvre Museum, Arc de Triomphe, Champs-Élysées, and Montmartre neighborhood.
	* Don't miss: A romantic Seine River cruise, a visit to the iconic Galeries Lafayette or Printemps department stores, and a performance at the Opéra Garnier.
2. **Lyon** (Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes)
	* France's gastronomic capital is known for: Exquisite cuisine, historical landmarks like the Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière and Roman Amphitheaters, and the vibrant Vieux Lyon (Old Lyon) district.
	* Don't miss: A wine and food tour, a visit to the famous Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse market, and a stroll along the Saône River.
3. **Bordeaux** (Nouvelle-Aquitaine)
	* The wine capital of the world is famous for: Wine tastings and tours, stunning 18th-century architecture, and the beautiful Place de la Bourse.
	* Don't miss: A wine cruise on the Garonne River, a visit to the Cité du Vin wine museum, and a stroll along the scenic Quai des Chartrons.
4. **Nice** (Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur)
	* The capital of the French Riviera is known for: Its picturesque Baie des Anges, Promenade des Anglais, and the iconic Chagall Museum.
	* Don't miss: A visit to the Lazareti Château, a stroll along the Old Town's narrow streets, and a day trip to the medieval town of Èze.
5. **Strasbourg** (Grand Est)
	* The capital of Alsace is famous for: Its stunning Gothic cathedral, picturesque canals, and vibrant Christmas market.
	* Don't miss: A visit to the Haut-Koenigsbourg Castle, a stroll along the River Ill, and a sample of the region's delicious Alsatian cuisine.
6. **Marseille** (Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur)
	* The second-largest city in France is known for: Its vibrant Vieux Port, Calanques (inlets), and iconic Basilique Notre-Dame de la Garde.
	* Don't miss: A boat tour of the Calanques, a visit to the MuCEM (Museum of European and Mediterranean Civilisations), and a taste of the city's famous bouillabaisse.
7. **Carcassonne** (Occitanie)
	* The medieval walled city is famous for: Its UNESCO World Heritage Site medieval fortress, Basilica of Saint-Nazaire, and stunning views of the surrounding countryside.
	* Don't miss: A guided tour of the citadel, a visit to the beautiful Saint-Louis d'Ansouis Castle, and a relaxing stroll along the Orbiel River.
8. **Reims** (Grand Est)
	* The champagne capital is known for: Its stunning cathedral, champagne cellars, and picturesque alleys.
	* Don't miss: A champagne tasting tour, a visit to the champagne houses like Veuve Clicquot or Taittinger, and a stroll along the River Vesle.
9. **Montpellier** (Occitanie)
	* The city of sunshine is famous for: Its beautiful Place de la Comédie, stunning beaches, and historic architecture.
	* Don't miss: A visit to the Cathedral of Saint-Pierre, a stroll along the Lez River, and a day trip to the medieval town of Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert.
10. **Rouen** (Normandy)
	* The capital of Normandy is known for: Its stunning cathedral, medieval quarter, and vibrant art scene.
	* Don't miss: A visit to the Joan of Arc Museum, a stroll along the Seine River, and a taste of the city's famous calvados.

These cities offer a mix of history, culture, gastronomy, and natural beauty that will leave you enchanted and eager to return to France.

instruction:
Answer the following question.

How do I compare strings in Java?
I've been using the == operator in my program to compare all my strings so far. However, I ran into a bug, changed one of them into .equals() instead, and it fixed the bug.
Is == bad? When should it and should it not be used? What's the difference?
output:
A great question about a common pitfall in Java!

In Java, the `==` operator checks whether two objects are identical, whereas the `equals()` method checks whether two objects have the same value.

When you use `==` to compare strings, you are actually comparing the memory addresses of the strings, not their contents. This is because `==` is an operator for reference equality, not value equality. In other words, `==` checks whether two objects are the same instance, not whether they have the same value.

Here's an example to illustrate this:
```java
String s1 = "Hello";
String s2 = "Hello";

System.out.println(s1 == s2); // true, because both point to the same memory address
```
However, if you create two separate strings with the same value, `==` will return `false`:
```java
String s3 = "Hello";
String s4 = new String("Hello"); // creates a new string object

System.out.println(s3 == s4); // false, because they are different objects
```
That's why your bug was likely caused by using `==` to compare strings, and why changing it to `equals()` fixed the issue.

When should you use `==` to compare strings?

Only when you are certain that you are comparing the same string object, such as when you have a reference to a string literal:
```java
String s = "Hello";
String t = "Hello";

System.out.println(s == t); // true, because both are the same string literal
```
In all other cases, use `equals()` to compare the values of the strings:
```java
String s = "Hello";
String t = " world";

System.out.println(s.equals(t)); // false, because they have different values
```
Remember, `equals()` is the correct way to compare strings in Java, unless you have a specific reason to use `==` (e.g., comparing string literals).

So, to summarize:

* `==` checks whether two objects are identical (reference equality).
* `equals()` checks whether two objects have the same value (value equality).

Choose the right one based on your needs!

instruction:
Design a programming problem related to the subject that has been given to you. Use some examples and constraints to improve your question.

Dynamic Programming
output:
Here's a programming problem related to Dynamic Programming:

**Problem:** Fibonacci Sequence with Memoization

The Fibonacci sequence is a series of numbers in which each number is the sum of the two preceding ones, usually starting with 0 and 1. However, for large values of n, calculating the nth Fibonacci number using a naive recursive approach can be very inefficient.

Your task is to write a function `fibonacci(n)` that calculates the nth Fibonacci number using dynamic programming with memoization. This means that you should store previously calculated Fibonacci numbers in a cache (or memo) to avoid redundant calculations.

**Example:**

Input: `fibonacci(5)`
Output: `5`

Explanation: The Fibonacci sequence for the first 5 numbers is: 0, 1, 1, 2, 3

Input: `fibonacci(8)`
Output: `21`

Explanation: The Fibonacci sequence for the first 8 numbers is: 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13

**Constraints:**

* The input `n` is a non-negative integer.
* The Fibonacci sequence is calculated up to `n` numbers.
* Your function should return the `n`-th Fibonacci number.
* You should use dynamic programming with memoization to avoid redundant calculations.

**Additional Tips:**

* You can use a dictionary or a hash table to store the memoized Fibonacci numbers.
* You should initialize the memo with the base cases of the Fibonacci sequence (i.e., `fibonacci(0) = 0` and `fibonacci(1) = 1`).
* You can use a loop to calculate the Fibonacci sequence up to `n` numbers.
* You should return the `n`-th Fibonacci number at the end of the function.

**Example Code:**
```
def fibonacci(n):
    memo = {0: 0, 1: 1}
    for i in range(2, n+1):
        memo[i] = memo[i-1] + memo[i-2]
    return memo[n]
```
This is just one possible solution, and you can improve it or come up with a more efficient algorithm. Good luck!

instruction:

instruction:
You will need to guide this person through the scenario they have described for the interview.

Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:
"Try to listen to what they're saying...but don't lose your train of thought...ugh, I can't do both!"
output:
Let's go through this scenario. You've finally come up with an algorithm for the coding question, and you're feeling relieved and ready to code it up. Just as you're about to start, your interviewer throws a curve ball at you.

"Take a deep breath," I suggest. "When your interviewer asks 'What if we thought of the problem this way?', it's not necessarily trying to trip you up or make you feel uncomfortable. It's a common technique used to gauge your problem-solving skills and adaptability.

"Instead of feeling like you need to abandon your original solution, try to listen to your interviewer's perspective and see how it relates to your own understanding of the problem. Remember, the goal is to solve the problem, not to stick rigidly to a single approach.

"So, take a moment to process what your interviewer is saying. Try to understand how their new perspective might change the landscape of the problem. Don't worry about losing your train of thought just yet – just focus on absorbing the new information and seeing what insights you can glean from it.

"Once you've had a chance to process the new information, you can begin to re-evaluate your original approach in light of this new perspective. You might find that your original solution still works, but with some adjustments. Or, you might see a completely new way to tackle the problem that you hadn't considered before.

"Remember, the key is to stay calm, stay focused, and keep an open mind. Your interviewer wants to see how you think, not just what you can code. So, take a deep breath, and let's see where this new perspective takes us!"

instruction:
You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.

Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;
output:
The problem is to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If a person doesn't have an address in the Address table, report null instead.

The implementation is using a LEFT JOIN operation to combine the Person table with the Address table on the 'personId' column. This is a common way to join two tables when you want to include all records from one table (in this case, the Person table), and the matching records from the other table (in this case, the Address table).

Here's a breakdown of how the LEFT JOIN works:

1. It takes all the records from the left table (Person) and matching records from the right table (Address) if they exist. If there are no matching records, it will return null on the right side.
2. Since we're doing a LEFT JOIN, the query will return all the records from the Person table, even if there are no matching records in the Address table.
3. If a person doesn't have an address in the Address table, the result will be a combination of the Person record with null for the city and state.

The SQL query is:

```
SELECT FirstName, LastName, City, State
FROM Person
LEFT JOIN Address
ON Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId;
```

This query:

1. Selects the columns 'FirstName', 'LastName', 'City', and 'State' from the result of the join.
2. Joins the 'Person' table with the 'Address' table on the 'personId' column using a LEFT JOIN.
3. Returns the result, which includes all records from the 'Person' table, even if there are no matching records in the 'Address' table. If there are no matching records, the 'City' and 'State' columns are returned as null.

The approach used is to combine the two tables using a LEFT JOIN, which allows us to include all records from the Person table, even if there are no matching records in the Address table. This ensures that we get all the data from the Person table, including those without addresses, and null values for the city and state if there are no matching records in the Address table.

instruction:
The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary.

Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine.
output:
I've found a few scientific errors that need to be corrected:

1. The correct spelling is "zinc" (not "zink").
2. The sentence "Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine" implies that excess zinc is harmlessly eliminated through urine, but this is not entirely accurate. While some excess zinc may be excreted in the urine, chronic excessive zinc intake can cause adverse effects, such as copper deficiency, iron deficiency, and changes in the gut microbiome.

Here is the corrected text:

Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. While zinc is generally considered safe, excessive intake can cause adverse effects, including copper deficiency, iron deficiency, and changes in the gut microbiome.

instruction:
Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output: The article discusses the relationship between mathematics and art, specifically in the visual arts. It highlights the long history of mathematical concepts being used in art, dating back to ancient Greece and the Italian Renaissance. The article mentions famous artists and mathematicians, such as Polykleitos, Luca Pacioli, Leonardo da Vinci, Piero della Francesca, Albrecht Dürer, M.C. Escher, and Piet Mondrian, who have incorporated mathematical concepts into their work. It also mentions the use of mathematics in various art forms, including textiles, Islamic art, and architecture. Overall, the article emphasizes the beauty and harmony that can be achieved when mathematics and art intersect.

instruction:
Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
Here's an improved version of the article:

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, has gained significant traction in recent years as a response to the exploitation of labor, environmental degradation, and social injustices in the global supply chain. The movement advocates for the adoption of robust labor, environmental, and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from low- and middle-income countries to high-income countries. This includes ensuring fair prices for farmers, safe working conditions, and environmental sustainability.

The concept of fair trade is rooted in the idea that trade should be governed by a set of principles that prioritize human well-being and dignity over profit. Proponents of fair trade argue that the current system of global trade is deeply flawed, as it often prioritizes the interests of corporations and wealthy nations over those of small-scale farmers, workers, and local communities.

The fair trade movement has sparked a broader debate about the need to reform the global trade system and ensure that it promotes social, environmental, and economic justice. Some argue that trade itself should be recognized as a human right, as enshrined in international law. This would require governments and corporations to prioritize human well-being and dignity in their trade policies and practices.

In addition to promoting fair labor practices and environmental sustainability, fair trade initiatives also aim to empower local communities and promote sustainable development. This includes supporting cooperatives and small-scale farmers, promoting local food systems, and reducing waste and carbon emissions.

As the global economy continues to evolve, the fair trade movement is likely to play an increasingly important role in shaping the future of international trade. By promoting fair and sustainable trade practices, we can help ensure that the benefits of globalization are shared more equitably and that the well-being of people and the planet is prioritized.

Elle consiste en l'étude, le diagnostic, la prévention, la gestion et le traitement des maladies, des troubles et des conditions de la bouche, en particulier centrée sur l'édentation (le développement et l'arrangement des dents) ainsi que la muqueuse orale.
